page.title: 06The Island - R.Lune-Tunstall
page.content: Erosion has caused the island which is inaccessible during winter and high water. Access is easy at other times over the pebbles. A Tunstall resident owns it but it is not farmed. Sheep and cattle wander across and graze it but the vegetation is different from the sown grass fields of the area. Gorse and Hawthorn,Briar and Dog Rose are the biggest bushes. Stumps of large trees, long dead, remain. Flowers common to uncultivated grassland are abundant. Clover,Crosswort,Hawkbit,Fox- gloves,Herb Robert,Self heal,King cup, Rest Harrow,Wild Thyme,Speedwell,Hare- bell and Yellow bed straw,Mimulus, Common Nettle and Butterbur grow on the pebbles. Mallard and Shelduck nest and swans are ever present. Summer visitors of Swifts and Swallows are many as are Oyster Catchers who nest on the pebbles.
